comments.commentBody: BOO!  My impressions ofthis excellent film asre very different from M.D.'s. I don't agree that Ma was a slighted character. Her resourcefulness, strength and love shone through every line she delivered.  The grip she had on her sanity, which must have been tenupus at times, was heroic. The chance she took to rescue Jack---not knowing whether she would be herself--was brave. The post-capiivity scenes were at times a little treacly, I thought, but Ma's breakdown was so believable, and understandable.Of course she was a victim!  I found the entire film --one that could have been unwatchable--a testiment to parental love.

Betsy,

Good point about Tom Hanks being too old. When Donovan was Hanks' age, he was dead. Hanks unquestionably has the gravitas for this kind of role, but his choice sums up what everyone should remember when they see this film: It's just a movie. I enjoyed it, but I didn't mistake it for anything other than Spielbergian entertainment.
I'll second that, Layer Cake is really a phenomenal movie and gripping, and Craig does a great job in it.

Dear Areader,
It is acceptable, but only if they have either self-declared their own gender like Caitlyn Jenner or Lady Gaga, or if they have made no claims either way going with the default and blatantly obvious gender is acceptable, up until contested by the subject.

Spot on review. This show has been Takei's passion project for a number of years, and I'm thankful that he was able to get it funded and produced while he could still star in a Broadway run. The story is touching and a welcome look at a shameful part of American history that is too often under-acknowledged. If only the creative team was better equipped to figure out how and why the show should sing, and didn't rely so heavily on cardboard cutouts, stock situations, and cheap rhymes.

I'm always excited to see more Asian-American actors and stories represented on the stage: Lea Salonga and Telly Leung sing beautifully and for the most part do what they can with the material (although they look in no way Japanese), and Michael K. Lee is revelatory (hopefully we won't have to wait another 10 years to see him back on Broadway). But it's frustrating when they're tied to mediocre shows that actually risk setting back progress. I can't imagine that Allegiance makes a strong argument, to either producers or theatergoers, that these stories and talents are worthwhile investments.

I don’t think Isherwood or anyone else is criticizing the musical for not being “mindlessly entertaining” enough. If there’s anything that the shows of Rodgers/Hammerstein, Sondheim, Kander/Ebb, etc. prove, it’s that musical theater can address “difficult” topics and cover complex emotional territory while still remaining fantastic entertainment. Isherwood’s main criticism of this particular show seems to be that it fails to find the right balance between the typical musical theater beats and the history lesson—and thus neither ends up feeling as involving or moving as they should be.

I can think of several “history lesson” musicals that are (to me, at least) entertaining, substantive, and even educational. See, for example, 1776, Pacific Overtures, and Hamilton.

Mind you, I haven’t seen Allegiance yet, so I’m not agreeing with Isherwood’s review. Based on what I’ve seen and heard so far, I’m optimistic that I’ll enjoy it when I see it in January.

Japanese-Americans of prominence in Hawaii were also sent stateside to the camps, including the grandfather of one of my friends. So distraught was he about his pregnant wife and several other children left behind that he reached for the barbed wire fencing in despair and was machine-gunned to death. When his eldest son reached adulthood years later, he had his father's body exhumed and cremated to be brought back to his family in Hawaii.

George Takei's "Allegiance" is a brave gesture from the heart, a gift to the country in which he could flourish.

I think Isherwood missed the point. To be able to attend a theater production on Broadway about the Japanese internment, told from an Asian American perspective, felt like a small miracle to my multi-racial family. Sitting in a predominantly Asian audience (another miracle on Broadway!), we were moved and inspired by the wonderful performances of the stellar cast, the narrative, music, sets, and lighting.

Allegiance broke the silence about the Japanese internment on Broadway and did so with artistic authenticity, passion, and enormous commitment from everyone involved. Attending was an important experience for my entire family, especially my teenage daughter, who faced many years of anti-Asian bullying in school. She left the theater with her head held a little higher, singing one of the songs that she'd found particularly inspiring. We highly recommend Allegiance and are grateful to George Takei and everyone else who helped bring it to Broadway!
I just saw it. It was genius on all points. Call it a dark comedy or a play that makes a point. I highly recommend it.

"Hir," a play by Taylor Mac, reviewed by Charles Isherwood.
Early on in his sensitive and balanced review, Isherwood rightly calls plays about dysfunctional families "this ever-enduring genre of American theater." In fact, last time I taught a course in modern American drama, nearly all the plays in my syllabus were family dramas, such as "Long Day's Journey Into Night," "Death of a Salesman," "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," "A Raisin in the Sun." "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" and "Buried Child."
There are many more to list. Taylor Mac's "Hir" is the latest in the genre, and, by no means, the last. which begs the question: Why are American playwrights so obsessed with the almost always disintegrating family? (The only plays in my list in which the families don't fall apart are by Lorraine Hansberry and Edward Albee.) My study of this feature of American drama
has disclosed to me a central truth about them: Each of the plays shows the audience that the disintegration, far from being pre-ordained, as in Greek tragedies, stems from the actions of highly flawed individuals, usually men.
The playwrights' persistent focus on the family also brought home to me
their unstated belief that families that sustain themselves are absolutely vital for the health of society.
I haven't seen Taylor Mac's seemingly exciting new play, "Hir," but it's strength seems to derive from a modern vision of the family that includes members in gender transition and no male playing the patriarch.
McGinnis is excellent in this show, which was charming and a relative bargain
Thought I heard that too. I was puzzled also.

I thought Patti said to Kevin early in the episode that if he loved his family, he should tell them about her, so I'm deeply puzzled about her saying he'd made a huge mistake after he told Nora. Does anyone else remember it this way? Am I the one hallucinating Patti now?
Did you really just refer to women as "meat"?

"El Condor Pasa" is indeed a spiritual/existential song (and far pre-dates Simon and Garfunkle's rendition). The song played was "I Am a Rock." From the chorus: "I am ... alone." All the characters are indeed, at the end of the day, alone in their struggles.
Since this episode had a symmetry involving thrown rocks (by Nora in the beginning and by Erika at the end), perhaps the writers were trying to add in the rocks' point of view. ;-))

Could there be any significance to Simon & Garfunkel playing during the credits? Although not the song played, Simon & Garfunkel's "Sparrow" is a wonderful song about a sparrow's struggle to survive and eventual death.
This network really needs to get over its Reagan fixation. And who says it doesn't pay to bring a knife to a gunfight?

This is the author's best column of the season by far, with very accurate criticisms.  Sadly, I think the author's hope that the absurd Dar/Saul scenes were meant to mask their suspicion of Allison is giving the show too much credit.
Peter is a bad man
That is the general speculation.

I agree that the whole Noah/ yoga section was predictible and silly. I think that all Allison meant was that she had not had sex for what seemed like the same period of time that Noah was unavailable to her.... and that there were unexpected psychological benefits from this celibacy. She was NOT saying she didn't want to resume sex so she could maintain her new clarity. What was getting in the way of her normal libido was her rage about the book.
I was sure she was feeling she was being raped and expected her to tell him she was done with him (at least for a while), so her announcement of pregnancy was a big surprise/downer.
It's a reality show on AMC with only 6 (I think) episodes. He'll be visiting and profiling bikers. you really think AMC would sacrifice they're cash cow?
No, you were making a reference to "Newhart". "The Bon Newhart Show" was the earlier one where he played a psychologist in Chicago.
I have been thinking the same thing. When they first got to Alexandria, I was relieved just so Carl could get a haircut and Darryl could take a shower.
If this incident made you "question your support of black youth," I doubt black youth even needed your support in the first place. He should never have had those young protesters arrested.

"All that's wanted is a sincere apology from former President Tim Wolfe and acknowledgement that racism at Mizzou is not a figment of the students' imaginations"

Actually, except for two apparently unrelated incidents, it probably is a figment of their imaginations. Did you even read this story, or the list of demands? What specific changes would you suggest, Heather? Please be specific and clear.

You assume the perpetrators of the listed events are college students.  I didn't see any information indicating that there was evidence that the perpetrators were mizzou students.   College campuses are very open and many people cross them all the time.    It could be that Wolfe assumed campus security would investigate the incidents; he is probably ill suited to personally conduct such an investigation.  What he probably didn't recognize is that the student body wanted lots of public denunciation of the acts and grand rallies and town hall meetings.  They wanted someone who understood public politics - which isn't Wolfe's forte (has he ever conducted a rally or town hall meeting for anything?).   At this time Mizzou needs someone with more of a public persona rather than an operations approach. With his resignation they will have that opportunity now.

Oh please. How much longer are people expected to wait for changes??!!! This is a ridiculous comment that shows your lack of understanding what the social issues are on this university campus. The person sitting at the top is ultimately  responsible.
